UNION OF INDIA 5 JJ., it needs no emphasis that individual rights are superior to the social rights - Civil and Human Rights The Constitution (Ninety-third Amendment) Act, 2005 and the enactment of the Central Educational Institutions (Reservation in Admission) Act, 2006 (5 of 2007) ("Act 5 of 2007") giving reservation to Other Backward Classes (OBCs), Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) were impugned in these writ petitions. Article 15(5) as inserted by the Constitution (Ninety-third Amendment) Act, 2005 reads as follows: "15(5). Nothing in this article or in sub-clause (g) of Clause (1) of Article 19 shall prevent the State from making any special provision, by law, for the advancement of any socially and educationally backward classes of citizens or for the Scheduled Castes or the Scheduled Tribes insofar as such special provisions relate to their admission to educational institutions including private educational institutions, whether aided or unaided, by the State, other than the minority educational institutions referred to in clause (1) of Article 30." Section 3 of Act 5 of 2007 provided for reservation of 15% seats for Scheduled Castes, 7½% seats for Scheduled Tribes and 27% for Other Backward Classes in only such State-aided institutions which were defined as "Central Educational Institutions" in Section 2(d) and not any other private unaided institutions. The percentage of reservation to various groups such as Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and Other Backward Classes was with reference to the annual permitted strength of the Central Educational Institutions. Section 5 of the Act mandated a proportionate increase of seats in the Central Educational Institutions over three years to provide for the abovesaid reservation. Though the reservation in favour of SCs and STs was not opposed by the petitioners, the reservation of 27% in favour of Other Backward Classes/Socially and Educationally Backward Classes was strongly opposed by various writ petitioners in these cases. Unanimously upholding the reservation in favour of OBCs subject to the exclusion of the "creamy layer", the Supreme Court Held: Per Balakrishnan, C.J. Reservation for admission in educational institutions or for public employment has been a matter of challenge in various litigations in the Supreme Court as well as in the High Courts. Diverse opinions have been expressed in regard to the need for reservation. Though several grounds have been raised to oppose any form of reservation, few in independent India have voiced disagreement with the proposition that the disadvantaged sections of the population deserve and need "special help". But there has been considerable disagreement as to which category of disadvantaged sections deserve such help, about the form this help ought to take and about the efficacy and propriety of what the Government has done in this regard. (Para 1) Reservation is one of the many tools that are used to preserve and promote the essence of equality, so that disadvantaged groups can be brought to the forefront of civil life. It is also the duty of the State to promote positive measures to remove barriers of inequality and enable diverse communities to enjoy the freedoms and share the benefits guaranteed by the Constitution. In the context of education, any measure that promotes the sharing of knowledge, information and ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. To cope with the modern world and its complexities and turbulent problems, education is a must and it cannot remain a cloistered for the benefit of a privileged few. Reservations provide that extra advantage to those persons who, without such support, can forever only dream of university education, without ever being able to realise it. This advantage is necessary. However, the fact remains that any reservation or preference shall not lead to reverse discrimination. Johnson: Harvard University Commencement Address, To Fulfill These Rights, 4-6-1965; Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg at the 51st Cardozo Memorial Lecture in 1999, referred to C Arjun Sen Gupta Report on "Conditions of Work and Promotion of Livelihood in the Unorganised Sector" (July 2007), cited Per Pasayat and Thakker, JJ. The respondents submit that while the Constitution really does not think of a casteless society, it prohibits untouchability in the background of Article 1 7. It has to be noted that both in Articles 15 and 16 the stress is on non-discrimination on the ground of caste. The Preamble of the Constitution also throws light on this d aspect. Ultimately, if the social status of a man goes in the higher direction because of his education, the difference in status gets obliterated. Education is a great leveller. In that sense, the ultimate object is that every Indian citizen could have the social status which is not inferior to another and that would be obliteration of the difference in status. The ultimate objective is to see that no person gets discriminated against because of his caste. If that be so, it would not be right to say that the ultimate objective is not a casteless society. (Para 238) e As has been conceded, affirmative action is not under challenge. Affirmative action is nothing but a crucial component of social justice in the constitutional dispensation but at the same time it has to be kept in view that the same does not infringe the principles of equality of which it is a part and/or unreasonably restrains or restricts other fundamental freedoms and that it does not violate the basic structure of the Constitution. (Para 325) f Classification on the basis of castes in the long run has tendency of inherently becoming pernicious. Therefore, the test of reasonableness has to apply. When the object is elimination of castes and not perpetuation to achieve the goal of casteless society and a society free from discrimination of caste, judicial review within the permissible limits is not ruled out. But at the same time compelling State interest can be considered while assessing backwardness. (Para 328) 9 The ultimate object is to bring those who are disadvantaged to a level where they no longer continue to be disadvantaged. It needs no emphasis that individual rights are superior to the social rights. All fundamental rights are to be read together. The inequalities are to be removed. Yet the fact that there has been no exclusion from the list of OBCs raises a doubt about the real concern to remove inequality. The ultimate objective is to bring people to a particular level so that h there can be equality of opportunity. In that context, one has to keep in view the ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. There should not be mere equality in law but equality in fact. (Paras 278 and 279) The necessary ingredients of equality essentially involve equalisation of unequals. Linked with this question the problem posed by the petitioners is whether reservation is the only way to equalise unequals? There are several methods and modes. If reservation really does not work as contended by the petitioners, then the alternative methods can be adopted. It is the stand of the respondents that not only reservations but other incentives like free lodging and boarding facilities have been provided in some States. (Para 280) Social empowerment cannot be and is certainly not a measure for only socially and educationally backward classes. It also has to be for the socially and economically backward classes. Unless this balance, which is very delicate, is maintained the system inevitably will develop a crack and this crack may after a certain point of time be difficult to be joined. Instead of lightening the society from castes or classes it will be overburdened and a point of time may come when we shall not be able to bear the burden any further. Timely steps in this regard will save the Indian society and democracy from a catastrophe of collapse because of something which the Constitution wants to obliterate. (Para 319) Per Raveendran, J. Caste has divided this country for ages. It has hampered its growth. To have a casteless society will be the realisation of a noble dream. To start with, the effect of reservation may appear to perpetuate caste. The immediate effect of caste-based reservation has been rather unfortunate. In the pre-reservation era people wanted to get rid of the backward tag-either social or economical. But post reservation, there is a tendency even among those who are considered as "forward", to seek the "backward" tag, in the hope of enjoying the benefits of reservations. When more and more people aspire for "backwardness" instead of "forwardness" the country itself stagnates. Reservation as an affirmative action is required only for a limited period to bring forward the socially and educationally backward classes by giving them a gentle supportive push. But if there is no review after a reasonable period and if reservation is continued, the country will become a caste divided society permanently. Instead of developing a united society with diversity, we will end up as a fractured society forever suspicious of each other. While affirmative discrimination is a road to equality, care should be taken that the road does not become a rut in which the vehicle of progress gets entrenched and stuck. Any provision for reservation is a temporary crutch. Such crutch by unnecessary prolonged use, should not become a permanent liability. It is significant that the Constitution does not specifically prescribe a casteless society nor tries to abolish caste. But by barring discrimination in the name of caste and by providing for affirmative action the Constitution seeks to remove the difference in status on the basis of caste. When the differences in status among castes are removed, all castes will become equal. That will be a beginning for a casteless egalitarian society. (Para 666) Per Bhandari, J. On careful analysis of the Constituent Assembly and the Parliamentary Debates, one thing is crystal clear: our leaders have always and unanimously proclaimed with one voice that our constitutional goal is to establish a casteless and classless society. It is our bounden duty and obligation to examine the ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. If a we permit this impugned legislation to be implemented, instead of a casteless and classless India, we would be left with a caste-ridden society. (Paras 364, 365 and 368) The original Framers of the Constitution did not intend to provide caste- based reservation in education to the backward classes. Soon after the Constitution was adopted, the very same Framers acted quickly to permit reservation for SC/ST/SEBCs in education by adding Article 15(4), vide the First b Amendment, to the Constitution. In doing so, they deviated from their own goal-the casteless society would have to wait. The First Parliament, by enacting Article 15(4), deviated from the original Framers' intent. They passed an amendment that strengthens, rather than weakening casteism. In Indra Sawhney case, 1992 Supp (3) SCC 217, the Supreme Court upheld this decision and bound us to a certain degree on this point. Indra Sawhney case has tied our c hands. Caste matters and will continue to matter as long as we divide society along caste lines. Caste-based discrimination remains. Violence between castes occurs. Caste politics rages on. Where casteism is present, the goal of achieving a casteless society must never be forgotten. Any legislation to the contrary should be discarded. (Paras 557,562 to 568,574 and 605) Indra Sawhney v. Union of India, 1992 Supp (3) SCC 217 : 1992 SCC (L&S) Supp 1 : (1992) 22ATC 385.Jollowed d The intention of Article 15 is to prohibit discrimination against citizens. This intention was only qualified for women and children. In fact, the original Framers rejected an amendment that would have watered down the prohibition in Article 15 against discrimination. A Member of the Constituent Assembly, Prof. K.T. Shah sought special protection for SC/STs. Prof. Shah effectively wanted the equivalent to Articles 15(4) and 15(5) in the Constitution but did not get it. e His amendment was negated. Dr. Ambedkar disagreed with Prof. Shah on the limited ground that it would have given States the green light to segregate SC/STs from General Category students. Dr. Ambedkar was concerned that special provisions would lead to negative discriminatory action in the guise of affirmative action. Whether or not this would have happened is unclear, but his concern seems well placed. A similar problem arises today, when the general category looks down upon or questions the qualifications of SC/ST/OBC f professionals: though the individual may have earned admission on marks alone, others may presume that reservation was a factor. Such a belief, regardless of veracity, cannot bode well for the career prospects of SC/ST/SEBCs. (Paras 569 to 571) In sum, by limiting Article 15(3) to women and children and rejecting an amendment equivalent to Article 15(4), the original Framers' intent was clear: no g special provisions for backward classes (SEBC/SC/STs) in education were to dilute Article 15(1)'s prohibition against discrimination based on caste. In the instant case, the Union of India argued that Article 15(4), inserted by the First Amendment to the Constitution, reflects the intent of the original Framers because it was passed by the same Members that drafted the original Constitution. In the Parliamentary Debates in 1951, Prime Minister Nehru argued in favour of amending the Constitution. He and other Members of the First Parliament, as distinguished from the original Framers who had drafted the original Constitution, did not hide their disapproval of Champakam Dorairajan, AIR 1951 SC 226. Article 15(4) was introduced to overturn that judgment. To justify Article 15(4), which represented a dramatic departure from equality as envisaged in Articles 15(2), (3) and 29(2), Nehru said that Article 15(4) would give effect to "what ... was really intended or should be intended". Notwithstanding parental duty, the State also has a role to play in ensuring that compulsory education is feasible. (Paras 450 and 452) Compulsory education has been introduced in one form or the other in various countries. From the historical experience of these nations, we learn that the legislation pertaining to compulsory education has played an important role in improving educational outcomes. (Para 461) When it comes to "compulsory education", the Central Government has made no such effort as the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan. Parliament has not passed any legislation. The executive has not issued any order. What we have is a patchwork of different State and Union Territory laws. Though, Section 7 of the Compulsory Education Bill, 2006 does envisage simultaneously targeting employers and parents. Employers would be punished when they hire a child to work too much or during school hours. Similarly, parents would also be punished for allowing this to happen. It must also be remembered that that it is not only the child who fails to attend but also the child who fails to enrol that has violated an attendance law. "Compulsory" connotes enforcement. Parliament rejected an amendment that would have saved parents from penal penalties. Those who wanted a safe haven from penal sanction for parents lost. From this vote, we know that Parliament intended to allow for future legislation that would impose penal sanctions for violations of legislation under Article 21-A. (Paras 453,455,456, 471 and 484 to 486) The Indian States' laws on compulsory education fail on two accounts: (1) they are too lenient to have a deterrent effect i.e. no State has provided for an adequate punishment whose effect would be to deter citizens from committing a violation, and (2) the legislation is not adequately implemented or enforced, in part, because it does not require police officers to do the job. Section 7, T.N. Compulsory Elementary Education Act, 1994 and Section 18(1), Delhi Primary Education Act, 1960 may be referred to in this regard. Some form of compulsory education has been on the statute books since 1917. However, neither the State Governments nor their police agencies are at all serious about implementing these compulsory laws. There are hardly any cases where even fines have been imposed. The Founding Fathers of the Constitution were aware of the ripples of inequality present in society, decried the notion of caste and ensured that the constitutional framework contained adequate safeguards that would ensure the upliftment of the socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, thus creating a society of equals. The interpretation of the term "socially and educationally backward", and its constituent classes, was left for future generations to decide. (Para 2) There is a long jurisprudential history as to whether caste can play any role in determining the socially and educationally backward classes of citizens (SEBCs). If the classification of SEBCs is done exclusively on the basis of caste, it would fly in the face of Article 15(1) of the Constitution. Determination of backward class cannot be exclusively based on caste. Poverty, social backwardness, economic backwardness, all are criteria for determination of backwardness. However, in Indra Sawhney case, 1992 Supp (3) SCC 217, which is a nine-Judge Bench decision, it was finally settled that the "caste" could be a beginning point and a determinative factor in identifying the socially and educationally backward classes of citizens. (Paras 133, 145 and 168) In Indra Sawhney case the majority held that the ideal and wise method would be to mark out various occupations, which on the lower level in many cases amongst Hindus would be their caste itself, and find out their social acceptability and educational standard, weigh them in the balance of economic conditions, and the result would be backward class of citizens needing a genuine protective umbrella. And after having adopted occupation as the starting point, the next point should be to ascertain their social acceptability. A person carrying on scavenging becomes an untouchable whereas others who were as low in the social strata as untouchables became depressed. The Court has cautioned that the backwardness should be traditional. Mere educational or social backwardness would not have been sufficient as it would enlarge the field thus frustrating the very purpose of the constitutional goal. It was pointed out that after applying these tests, the economic criteria or the means test should be applied since poverty is the prime cause of all backwardness as it generates social and educational backwardness. (Para 146) The petitioners contended that caste cannot be used even as one of the criteria for identifying SEBCs as many persons have shifted their traditional occupations and have become doctors, engineers and lawyers. But these are only a few cases and even such persons continue to suffer social segregation based on caste. Caste plays an important role in determining the backwardness of the individual. In society, social status and standing depend upon the nature of the occupation followed. (Paras 147 and 148) "Caste" is often used interchangeably with "class" and can be called as the basic unit in social stratification. The most characteristic thing about a caste group is its autonomy in caste related matters. One of the universal codes enforced by all castes is the requirement of endogamy. Other rules have to do with the regulations pertaining to religious purity or cleanliness. Sometimes it restricts occupational choices as well. It is not necessary that these rules be enforced in particular classes as well, and as such a "class" may be distinguished from the broader realm of "caste" on these grounds. Castes were often rated, on a purity scale, and not on a social scale. According to the early sociological theories, the term "caste" has been used to mean "class", hereditary or rigid status, and hereditary occupation. A class always enjoys certain privileges or at least certain advantages over others in society. When it is more or less rigorously closed, or enjoys hereditary privileges, it is called a "caste". a (Paras 149 and 152 to 154) It is possible that within a caste group there is a marked inequality of status, opportunity, or social standing-which then defines the "class" within that particular "caste" system. For example, all the Brahmins are not engaged in highly respectable employment, nor are all very wealthy. It may even be that some Brahmins may be servants of members of a lower caste, or it may also be b so that the personal servant of a rich Brahmin may be a poor Brahmin. Hence, there is every reason to believe that within a single caste group there are some classes or groups of people to whom good fortune or perseverance has brought more dignity, social influence and social esteem than it has to others. (Para 156) In India, caste, in a socio-organisational manner would mean that it is not characterised merely by the physical or occupational characteristics of the individuals who make it up; rather, it is characterised by its codes and its close- c knit social controls. In the case of classes, however, there may not exist such close-knit unit social controls, and there may exist great disparity in occupational characteristics. (Para 157) A social class is therefore a homogeneous unit, from the point of view of status and mutual recognition; whereas a caste is a homogeneous unit from the point of view of common ancestry, religious rites and strict organisational d control. Thus the manner in which the caste is closed both in the organisational and biological sense causes it to differ from social class. Moreover, its emphasis upon ritual and regulations pertaining to cleanliness and purity differs radically from the secular nature and informality of social class rules. In a social class, the exclusiveness would be based primarily on status. Social classes divide homogeneous populations into layers of prestige and esteem, and the members of each layer are able to circulate freely with it. In a caste, however, the social e distance between members is due to the fact that they belong to entirely different organisations. It may be said, therefore, that a caste is a horizontal division and a class, a vertical division. (Paras 158 and 159) Indra Sawhney v. Amendments by their very nature are often enabling provisions. It can strike down the entire amendment ab initio. The question of potential width was resolved in Minerva Mills, (1980) 3 SCC 625, paras 38-39. The Fourteenth Amendment to the US Constitution inter alia provides that no State shall "deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws". Whereas in India, Articles 14 to 18 are differently structured and contain express provisions for special provision for the advancement of SEBCs, STs and SCs. While considering the constitutionality of a social justice legislation, it is worthwhile to note the objectives which have been incorporated by the Constitution-makers in the Preamble of the Constitution and how they are sought to be secured by enacting fundamental rights in Part III and directives principles of State policy in Part IV of the Constitution. The fundamental rights represent the civil and political rights and the directive principles embody social and economic rights. Together they are intended to carry out the objectives set out in the Preamble of the Constitution. In the Indian Constitution there is a specific provision under the directive principles of State policy in Part IV of the Constitution requiring the State to strive for justice-social, economic and political-and to minimise the inequalities of income and endeavour to eliminate inequalities in status, facilities and opportunities (Article 38). The United States Supreme Court has evolved three standards of review for Government action that treats different people differently. The first is the rational basis standard. When the classification is rationally related to any legitimate Government purpose, the c Court defers to the State and upholds the classification. This is the most deferential of the three standards. The second standard is intermediate scrutiny, which is less deferential to the Government. Our Constitution has been amended ninety-four times. Time and again the Supreme Court has struck down certain measures having been taken by the Governments either Union or States as being unconstitutional. The response of Parliament is when such situation comes to resort to amend the Constitution itself. Even sometime retrospectively to implement exactly what they feel is politically convenient. This is particularly evident with regard to the contentious issues regarding reservation for the Other Backward Classes (OBC) and exclusion of the "creamy layer". The issue of reservation raised a serious controversy in the early 1990s, which finally led to the historic Mandal case8• 11. In Indra Sawhney v. Union of India8 the Supreme Court held that: (i) Reservations should not exceed 50% of the jobs to be filled; (ii) Reservations could be provided only at the time of entry into government service but not in matters of promotion; (iii) The total quantum of reservation should not exceed 50% even if the carried forward vacancies were taken into account. 12. Over the years the person from the reserved category got the twin advantages having accelerated promotion as also with consequential seniority. This was held to be unconstitutional in Union of India v. Virpal Singh Chauhan9 . In another case it was also held that there should be no relaxation of qualifying marks in any examination or lowering the standards of evaluation. This view has been expressed by this Hon'ble Court in S. Vinod Kumar v. Union of India 10. Each of these principles laid down by the Supreme Court stands nullified by series of amendments made to the Articles 16 and 335 of the Constitution itself. Now each of these principles laid down by this Hon'ble Court have been diluted in one stroke by legislative process, which shows the bent of mind of the political parties. Determination of backward classes-An approach 115 9. One of the very important issues today is, while determining the backwardness of the citizens, whether one should apply vertical division or horizontal division. Horizontal approach leads to loose heterogeneous group, allows stepwise advancement of society, is dynamic in nature, and gives equal opportunity to every one irrespective of race, caste, place of birth and religion. This Hon'ble Supreme Court in Indra Sawhney v. Union of India 1 (SCC pp. 772-725) while deliberating on "means test" and "creamy layer" have applied horizontal approach in deciding the concept of "creamy layer". The various parameters forming the basis of horizontal approach have to be dynamic, situation based, reviewable and may be different at various steps of advancement. Bird's eye view of vertical approach 10. When the British first gained a foothold on Indian subcontinent in 18th century, their concern was profit. After 1857 uprising, the freebooters of 18th century gave way to bureaucrat of 19th century. From the mixed belief of their superiority and fascination to rule the world, the new administrators adopted new policy of dividing the society vertically as one of the tools for ruling the country. The British administrators were overwhelmed by ruling the greater number of people than anywhere else in the Empire, which made them to compartmentalise chunks of population with manageable groups. The most obvious way to do so was the use of India's unique caste and religious systems. The British in India used the census not only to count but made it an active participant in creation and modification of society and used the vertical approach to prolong British abilities to rule India. India not only inherited its Constitution from the British but also mindset to rule. It is evident that the framers of the Constitution, even after realising the ill effects of vertical division, adopted the same with an aim to rule. With the advent of coalition politics, the subdued side effects of vertical approach have became more evident and palpable. Though similar instances have been seen in the past, but the recent movement of Gujjars to be included in Scheduled Tribes in Rajasthan, should make all Indians to seriously rethink about the role of vertical approach in dividing the society. At international level, Ceylon and Iraq are two burning examples facing the outcome of vertical division. Even English society is facing the fallout of vertical division, which they used as a successful tool to rule. Caste and determination of Backward Classes 11. The role of "caste" in determination of backward classes is being argued by learned advocates before the Hon'ble Supreme Court. What I wish to highlight about the two stands being taken by every Government in power for many years: neither the Government in power is ready to decry the word "caste" for determination of backward classes nor is ready to carry out census including caste as one of the indicators. So it is humbly submitted that if this Hon'ble Supreme Court feels that caste plays a major role in delineation of backward classes, than it should rule that caste wise enumeration of population may also be undertaken in the ensuing census. But with the Constitution of India 1950, India having set its face against a casteless society for the future, it was this that compelled every successive Government at the Centre in each census to eschew questions regarding caste. 7. The argument of those who resist excluding the creamy layer (the more forward of the backward classes) is that if the particular caste is itself taken as a "class" there is no warrant in law to exclude anyone including the most forward/the more fortunate from that caste. Venugopal, Senior Advocate, for the petitioners (contd.) 147 (A) From the very inception of the Constitution, Article 15(4) was a provision and a source of legislative power for the purpose of making reservations for Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs) as well as for Socially and Educationally Backward Classes (SEBCs) of citizens in aided minority educational institutions. This is apparent from the following: (i) The object of the insertion of Article 15(4) after the decision in State of Madras v. Champakam Dorairajan 1. (i) The decisions of this Hon'ble Court from Balaji2 to Nagaraj 3 . (ii) The various reservation legislations enacted by J&K, Uttar Pradesh, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.4 (iv) The very fact that Article 29(2) is referred to in Article 15(4) which deals with admissions to institutions, etc. On the other hand, Article 15(5) which provides for reservation of seats for SCs & STs as well as SEBCs in aided educational institutions expressly excludes such reservation being made at all in minority educational institutions covered by Article 30(1) of the Constitution. (B) Article 15(4) operates with a qualification that nothing in Article 15 or in Article 29(2) of the Constitution shall prevent the State from making such special provisions for SCs and STs as well as SEBCs, while Article 15(5) operates with a qualification that nothing in Article 15 or in Article 19(1 )(g) shall prevent the State from making such special provisions for SCs and STs as well as SEBCs. The qualifying words in Article 15(4) do not have any real meaning or effect for the reason that both Article 15(1) as well as Article 29(2) prohibit discrimination on grounds only of religion or caste. A special provision for reservation for SCs and STs or SEBCs can never be only on the grounds of religion or caste as it is the attributes of the religious group or the caste group in the nature of backwardness which results in the special preference and not merely their religion or caste. If so, Article 15(4) provides reservation for SCs and STs as well as SEBCs in aided minority educational institutions while Article 15(5) prohibits the same resulting in direct conflict between the two. Thus, quotas create unqualified people who win f the lottery of quotas by patronage without achieving the enhancement of capacities. 2.13. This approach is unsound and disturbs the equality of other meritorious people without any advantage to the group. (cl) Disempowerment in respect of the power of the State and political non- representation It should be borne in mind that India has a large number of people who live below the poverty line; and, therefore, the system of exclusion must be clear and just so that the chances of similarly placed poor and salaried sectors are not adversely affected. 2.15. It is self-evident that there is no settled criteria in respect of the definition of Backward classes-and, in particular Other Backward Classes (OBCs). The Constitution identifies SCs, STs and social and educationally backward classes (SEBCs) in Articles 15(4), (5) and 340; and backward and any backward classes (BCs) in Article 16(4). The term OBC is to be found nowhere in the Constitution but has been invented by various governments and the courts to signify the Other Backward Classes (OBCs), who in addition to the SC and ST. Inevitably, there is a confusion as between the SEBCs and the OBCs who are not interchangeable. The term OBC as inducted into Article 15 is obviously wider than the term SEBC in Article 15. 2.16. In the Indra Sawhney case8, it was pointed out that: (a) as far as the range of affirmative action is concerned, Article 15(4) is wider than Article 16(4) (at SCC p. 756, para 846) (b) as far as the test of backwardness is concerned, Article 16(4) is wider than Article 15(4) (at SCC p. 727, paras 796-97) It is therefore a constitutional requirement that the identification and range of affirmative action must be addressed with considerable rigour and strict scrutiny on behalf of the state since the rights of the excluded (namely those not recognised) would be directly affected. SUSPECT LEGISLATION, STRICT SCRUTINY AND NARROW TAILORING 75. Under the constitutional scheme, the state is permitted to classify on an c intelligible differentia under Articles 14 and 15(1) itself. Where however the "Purpose" for which the classification is to be made impinges the fundamental rights of others (in the present case Articles 19 and 29(2) of the Constitution) or if the government chooses to identify a backward class on a criteria which is among the prohibited classifications under the constitutions itself, then the classification would be per se suspect and would therefore call for strict scrutiny and narrow tailoring by the court to ensure that the mode of classification chosen is a not garb for a deeper d intent of self promotion and laced with vested political interests directed towards disintegration and division in the society. The measure chosen would then have to be narrowly tailored such that the means are strictly to achieve the goals and no "additional" benefits may accrue to any person. 76. It has been argued by the Central Government as well as the states that the principle of "strict scrutiny" and "Narrow tailoring" are American concepts which e cannot be adopted in Indian conditions. It has been argued that in India there is a presumption of the validity of a legislative enactment and judicial interference is limited. It is submitted that there is undoubtedly a presumption in favour of an enactment but where the enactment is for conferment of affirmative action benefits i.e. conferring benefits in preference to others or by classifying, and that too on a basis which is expressly prohibited by the Constitution then such legislations are per se suspect. The rule being "equality" and the doctrine of classification an exception f to the rule to achieve larger equality. Thus unless the classification can be sustained as being for a legitimate objective and measure for classification on an intelligible differentia, such legislations cannot be sustained. 77. The test of strict scrutiny is not alien to the Indian judicial system and has been used by this Hon'ble Court in the case of Nair Service Society v. State of Kerala22 (see SCC p. 25, para 47). 78. RELEVANCE OF AMERICAN JUDGMENTS AND THE STRICT SCRUTINY TEST IN THE INDIAN CONTEXT 7 .1 The American doctrines and tests relating to "strict scrutiny," "compelling b statements" and "narrow tailoring" are tests which are premised on an approach which does not apply to India at all. These proceed on the basis that any attempt to take measures on the basis of race are discriminatory in the first instance as they affect individual rights. If this is so, then the measures have to be subjected to the strict scrutiny test and can be upheld if they narrowly tailored to suit compelling State interest and it has been so held. In Saurabh Chaudri v. Union of India 12 the c Constitution Bench was asked to strike down institutional preference as being suspected classification incapable of withstanding the strict scrutiny test. This contention was repelled at SCC pp. 163-64, paras 35-37. 7 .2 Therefore, it is clear that under our system, there is presumption of constitutionality, and as mentioned above, there is a greater presumption of constitutionality under the scheme of equality which mandates positive steps to d remove backwardness. 7 .3 At this stage it must be noted that in this very case, Justice Sinha wrote what is described as a 'concurring judgment' and in paras 86 and 87, referred to American judgments quoted from the judgment in Jennifer Gratz and Patrick Hamacher v. If this judgment is to be read as accepting that the strict scrutiny test is to be applied in India, then it is not, to that extent, a concurring judgment, but in this aspect it would have to be held to be not in accordance with the majority judgment. 7.4 The context of Justice Sinha's observations in Nair Service So ciety case22 f have to be read with reference to Saurabh Chaudri case 12 (to elaborate). Indian Constitution specifically contains provisions like Articles 15(4) and 16(4), which permit special provisions for backward classes, and not backward individuals. Hence, our Constitution specifically permits class based reservation. Further, we have already seen how the Supreme Court has categorically declared class based reservation to be a facet of Articles 14, 15(1) and 16(1) itself, and not merely an exception. Hence, if class based reservations are a facet of Articles 14 and 15(1) and 16(1) itself, they cannot be assumed to be suspect because they cannot be assumed to be violative of the individual right of equality, and therefore cannot be subjected to strict scrutiny. 7.7 Therefore, the American law upholds race-based affirmative action only when the same is individual specific, without compromising on the merit of the beneficiary of affirmative action. This affirmative action is justified by saying that cultural diversity helps the entire student body or the society in understanding each other and enriches their lives. Hence, at all times, the focus is on how the affirmative action will benefit the white population. In India, on the other hand, there is no enrichment benefit to be drawn for the majority through affirmative action. The Indian law is very clear that our caste system has historically suppressed the backward classes in the most hideous ways, and therefore we must now make them come up into the mainstream. The focus here is on the encouragement of the backward classes, and not how their being in the mainstream will help the forward classes. Further, we are not looking for any cultural diversity through affirmative action since we are diverse enough as it is, and the backward classes are essentially from the same cultural background. Lastly, we do not make a pretence about the fact that the backward classes cannot compete with the forward classes. Whereas in America it is essential that the beneficiary of the affirmative action must be able to compete with the rest. To adopt this as the position in India will be to miss the entire point, that the se backward classes due to the past injustices are in no position to compete with the mainstream, and they need affirmative action to push them up. So all the assumptions that our Constitution rests on stem from the fact that equality is an individual right, while affirmative action is a class based measure. So, when we judge it as a class based measure, we cannot rely on a jurisdiction that does not even recognise class based rights under the equality doctrine. VIII. Union of India24, Jeevan Reddy, J. observed that the opinion of the Law b Ministry and the reply of Minister of State for Finance in Parliament is not of much relevance for the construction of the sub-clause under consideration in that case. XI. MUST THERE BE A TIME-LIMIT FOR RESERVATION? 11.1 It is submitted that conceptually there cannot be any time-limit imposed for the policy of reservation in admission or in employment. The policy of reservation flows from the mandate of equality and till the time the constitutional objective of 'real equality' is achieved, there is a Constitutional mandate on the State to have special provisions in the nature of reservation for the upliftment of backward classes. 11.2 It is further submitted that the policy of reservation is framed in the instant case by the legislature and the legislature would itself review to ascertain the advances made and grounds achieved. 11.3 It cannot be forgotten that reservations in Central Government Educational Institutions are sought to be introduced for the first time after 57 years of the coming into force of Constitution. It is the beginning of a long overdue process of social engineering. Significant start has been made. It is respectfully submitted that this is not the time to set time-limits. 11.4 In matters of this kind, namely, removal of backwardness, removal of untouchability and achieving a caste free society, there can be no time limits. REAL EQUALITY-THE INDIAN VIEW Introduction: What Equality is Not 76. Having studied the development and current pos1t10n in US law and the reasons why adopting that position is neither permissible nor appropriate for India, this section of submissions concentrates on the equality discourse in India. 77. The issues before this Court are not simply related to admission to educational institutions. Rather, it is a debate about the meaning to be given to the fundamental right to equality enshrined in Part III of the Constitution and the rights a b of those who are specially spoken about by the Constitution. Is the constitutional obligation on the State merely that it will treat people equally, or is the obligation something more-that the State will take positive steps; will strive to create an equal Indian society? It is respectfully submitted that it has to be the latter. The positive c constitutional obligation involves in its very essence the stepping beyond frontiers of formal equality and taking such steps as necessary to create an equal Indian society. 78. In A Theory of Justice, John Rawls discusses different conceptions of equality.39 The first model he considers is the "system of natural liberty". In such a system, positions are open to all those able and willing to strive for them. Whatever distribution is achieved in this manner is taken as a just system. (b) This issue does not find a place in the questions referred to this Constitution Bench for adjudication by the Order of reference. (c) It has no direct relation with the question that this Bench is considering, i.e. reservation for SEBCs in central educational institutions. 121. There are other constitutional provisions concerning the care of children below the age of six. The main function of the Commission among others was to review the provisions of the Constitution dealing with Parts III and IV, inter alia the fundamental rights and the fundamental duties of the state. 42. Chapter 3, Volume I of the report is dedicated to fundamental rights, directive principles and the fundamental duties of the state. While reviewing Articles 15 and 16 of the Constitution in the context of reservation for minorities the Commission held that "there was a plea on behalf of some minority communities for an express provision for reservations in favour of minorities both in Articles 15(4) and 16(4). The application of strict scrutiny test, as applied in America, involving aspects of compelling State interest, narrow tailoring, and suspect classifications, are really matters pertaining to the standard of judicial review. The question is whether they can be adopted by Indian Courts under the Indian Constitutional system, particularly in matters of reservation or making of special provisions. 28. The expression "strict scrutiny" by itself does not indicate much unless the content of the strict scrutiny becomes clear. For instance, the twin test of classification expounded by our courts in R.K. Dalmia25 and Special Courts Bill23 are applied identically with respect to the challenges based on Article 14 in different spheres, except that in the field of tax and economics our courts are liberal and allow a wider latitude. (See R.K. Garg case26). In other fields, the courts may be less liberal or relatively stricter but the twin test remains the same. Again in matters pertaining to a challenge based on Article 19(1 ), the scrutiny in matters of freedom of speech and expression, the freedom to peacefully assemble without arms and the freedom to form associations or unions are given a stricter scrutiny. But that is on account of the narrow heads of reasonable restrictions permitted by Articles 19(2)(3) and (4). Thus the Constitution itself delineates a stricter regime. However, the scope of the expression "reasonable restrictions" remains the same and the tests are always as laid down in the classical case of V.G. Row27 and Pathumma28 . 29. In United States the strict scrutiny test has acquired a specific legal connotation. Under the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendment, the US courts apply different standards in different areas depending upon whether the classification is suspect or not. If the classification is suspect, then the strict scrutiny would involve a close enquiry of whether there exists a compelling state of interest and whether the law is narrowly tailored. There are 4 aspects involved in the Fourteenth amendment. First, all persons born or naturalised in the US are citizens of the US and of the States wherein they reside. Second, there is an injunction that State shall not make or enforce any law which shall abridge the privileges and immunities of the citizen. Third, the States are injuncted against depriving any person of life, liberty or property without due process a of law. Fourth, there is an injunction against denial of equal protection of laws. In view of this peculiar combination of entitlements, the US courts have exercised Due b Process powers within the field of Equal Protection of Laws. Accordingly, the US courts make value judgments as to whether a particular legislation is suspect and whether it touches certain interests which are fundamental. This involves an a priori determination and application of a scale of values judicially determined depending upon significance of the field or interest touched by the legislative classification. The interests stand judicially classified as fundamental, less fundamental or not c fundamental. Upon this operates theory of suspect classification. 31. Initially, the US Courts considered discriminations against classes which have been historically subjected to unequal treatments or which were in a politically powerless position as cases of suspect classification. The underlying rational of the suspect classification theory is that where legislation affects discreet & insular minorities, the presumption of constitutionality fades because traditional political d process may have broken up. See Donald E. Johnson v. William Robert Robison29 . Subsequently, this theory was extended to all classification based on race, religion, sex and some other categories. It was said that Fourteenth Amendment commands the elimination of the racial barriers, not their creation in order to satisfy our theory as to how society ought to be organised. See De Funis v. Charles Odegaard30 . 32. An important input for holding that classifications based on race as suspect e was the enactment of the Civil Rights Act, 1964. It prohibits discriminatory preference for any group whether in minority or majority i.e. irrespective of whether they are black or white. (See American Jurisprudence, Ilnd Vol. 15, pp. 717 to 720). It is akin to Article 15(1) of our Constitution, but does not contain other sub-articles. 33. It is significant that even the US Supreme Court has not gone as far as to characterise any Constitutional Amendment as suspect classification. As already submitted by the Solicitor General (SG), Articles 15(3), 15(4), 15(5) and 16(4) are f nothing but an emphatic expression of valid classification done by the Constitution itself. This is based on the verdict of Indra Sawhney. The legislations made thereunder only carry out the constitutional mandate. Since the constitution itself makes the classification, the theory of suspect classification applied to legislations in America is wholly inapplicable. 34. This is another reason for inapplicability of suspect classification. NARROW TAILORING 36. The United States Supreme Court has devised the idea of narrow tailoring as part of strict scrutiny test. This concept means that the legislature must consider all alternative ways to achieve the determined goal which should be legitimate and it must adopt that reasonable way to achieve the goal which imposes lesser burden on constitutionally protected activity. The State should not chose the way of greater c interference but must chose less drastic means. Thus the US Supreme Court while exercising the power of judicial review, based on strict scrutiny, examines various alternative means or ways available for achieving the legitimate goal chosen by the State and then decides whether the chosen means or way is the least drastic one. In this way, the US Supreme Court enters into the domain of policy determination. The Indian courts have scrupulously refrained from entering into the domain of policy determination or policy evaluation while exercising the power of judicial review. This Court has emphasised that it does not sit in appeal over a policy decision and does not substitute nor does it examine the wisdom of the policy choice. It interferes with policy decision only when it finds the policy to be palpably arbitrary, mala fide or discriminatory. Analysis of the Constitutional Provisions: 7.1.1. Clause (4) of Article 15 was introduced by an amendment made in the year 1951. It is, therefore, necessary for us to look into the pertinent provisions of the Constitution as enacted before the said amendment. • Clause ( 4) of Article 16 uses the term "class of citizens". • Clause (1) of Article 340 uses the term "Socially and Educationally d Backward Classes." • Clause (10) of Article 338, which was originally enacted as Clause (3) of Article 338, corresponds to Article 301 of the Draft Constitution and reads as under: Article 338(10) 7.1.2. From this, it is very clear that Clause (4) of Article 15 does not create new a classes. It does not apply to individuals. Caste is a deep-rooted phenomenon. It conditions everyone's mind. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar said that there is no Hindu without a caste. That being the position, it is extremely difficult to get an objective and impartial analysis of the Constitutional and legal provisions on the issue of 'Backward Classes' in India. However, Prof. Marc Galanter, Professor of Law School, University of Wisconsin and presently a visiting Professor at the National Law School of India, University, Bangalore, is the author of a book titled 'Competing Equalities' -Law and the Backward Classes in India. This book is, by far, the most objective and impartial commentary on the subject. It has been widely quoted all over the world particularly, where affirmative action is in practice. He makes out a strong case to demonstrate that a caste is a class. It is noteworthy that Prof. Galanter has come out with a declaration, after extensive research and analysis. It is worth quoting him: "The Constitution names as the permissible recipients of preferences, not backward individuals or families, nor backward castes, religious communities, occupational or regional groups, but backward "classes" of citizens. These "classes" are restricted neither to economic classes nor to classes in the senses familiar to modem social science. The term seems to be used in the broad connotation of any group of persons having certain common characteristics. In particular, it would seem to include, though it is not confined to, those classifications otherwise forbidden in Articles 15, 16 and 29(2)-e.g. racial, religious, and caste groups. This is so because Articles 15(4) and 16(4) are exceptions or provisos to these Articles, limiting the operation of their provisions. Because of the lowest status, they were not even touched by the caste-Hindus. They were subjected to all forms of exploitation and social injustice. I refrain from writing on caste, for the topic is not material at this juncture. A few of the disabilities certain castes have been subjected to are intended to be removed by the Untouchability (Offences) Act, 1955. The social backwardness with those castes was due to the social disabilities imposed on them. The disabilities were imposed because of their caste, that is to say, low status. 13. In the present context of our society and the constitutional provisions caste-compartments are bund to continue. Constitution by Article 17 abolishes "Untouchability". But it does not abolish caste-groups. When the Indian mind is yet conservative and when there are no provisions in the Constitution for the removal of caste-groups there can be no legislation in that behalf, and Hindus are bound to maintain the caste-groups. The Directive Principles of State Policy are intended for taking certain measures such as prohibiting consumption of alcohol, providing for free and compulsory education, removing English as the medium of instruction, organising village panchayats, etc. But there is no policy for the eradication of castes. As the Preamble goes, the people of India in giving to themselves the Constitution in the present form did not think that abolition of caste-compartments was a function of the State. This omission in the Constitution is one that makes our country a secular democratic welfare State. What the Constitution intends doing is the abolition of differences in 'status' on the ground of caste, and removal of disabilities that are attended with low status. The hither to unknown belief that some castes are above and some below is intended to be done away with. The division of society into various groups in the graded order should go. But he divisions could be on equal footing or status. This is exactly what Mahatma Gandhi said about the removal of castes. He said: "I have frequently said that I do not believe in caste in the modern sense. It is an excrescence and a hardship on progress. The constitutional amendment, the impugned Act and the 27% reservation in favour of Backward Classes is an unprecedented leap taking the higher education in the country forward, without depriving a single seat to the forward castes. The advanced castes, with a population of less than 20% will still be able to corner up to c 50% seats in the name of merit disproportionate to their known proportion of population. Diverse opinions have been expressed in regard to the need for reservation. Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, who presided over the Congress Expert Committee emphasised before the Constituent Assembly that the removal of socio-economic inequalities was the highest priority. It was held that the validity of an ordinary law can be questioned and when it is questioned it must be justified by reference to a higher law. Equality is a multicoloured concept incapable of a single definition as is also the fundamental right under Article 19(1)(g). The principle of equality is a delicate, vulnerable and supremely precious concept for our society. It is true that it has embraced a critical and essential component of constitutional identity. The larger principles of equality as stated in Articles b 14, 15 and 16 may be understood as an element of the "basic structure" of the Constitution and may not be subject to amendment, although, these provisions, intended to configure these rights in a particular way, may be changed within the constraints of the broader principle. It is also possible that more backward classes cannot afford to compete with the less backward classes. The only way to solve the said problem is by categorisation of Backward Classes and f subclassifying them so as to ensure that under each category only similarly circumstanced castes are grouped together. The categorisation of backward class has successfully worked in the State of Tamil Nadu where most backward class is provided 20% reservation and the most backward castes and denotified tribes are grouped together and the backward classes are provided 30% reservation. In the State of Karnataka, backward classes are 9 divided into five categories and separate reservations have been provided. It is to be understood that "creamy layer" principle is introduced merely to exclude a section of a particular caste on the ground that they are economically advanced or educationally forward. They are excluded because unless this segment of caste is excluded from that caste group, there cannot be proper identification of the backward class. If the "creamy layer" principle is not applied, it could easily be said that all the castes that have been included among the socially and educationally backward classes have been included exclusively on the basis of caste. Identification of SEBC for the purpose of either Articles 15(4), 15(5) or 16(4) solely on the basis of caste is expressly prohibited by various decisions of this Court and it is also against Article 15(1) and Article 16(1) of the Constitution. It may be noted that the "creamy layer" principle is applied not as a general principle of reservation. It is applied for the purpose of identifying the socially and educationally backward class. Ordinarily, grounds of attack of a legislation is whether the legislature has legislative competence or whether the legislation is ultra vires the provisions of the Constitution. They may be summarised as follows: 1. In determining whether the valid parts of a statute are separable from the invalid parts thereof, it is the intention of the legislature that is the determining factor. The central concern then is how to inculcate a sense of 'common brotherhood' among people with divergent histories and who occupy a vastly different positions in the economic and social structure of a society. Before we go further on discussing the specifics of caste and reservations in India it is worth recording that liberty and equality can sometimes be contradictorily positioned. This is why it is important for democracy to redress these community-based grievances within a b framework that does not violate liberal principles. While the individual needs to be protected, there are individuals in certain groups and communities that need safeguards and support as well. After all it must be remembered that communities do not create citizens, but that there are citizens within communities. Also, while it is rather risky to say that communities have rights, there is no doubt at all that within liberal c democracies, individuals have rights. Indeed, these rights were secured historically so that individuals did not have to be burdened by community and ascriptive pressures on them. The rationale behind affirmative action is that it releases suppressed talents and expands the pool of social assets in society for the general d good. If today we are looking for a justification for affirmative action in this fashion, several decades ago it was precisely this enlarging of the social pool of talents that recommended equal treatment for women. As L. T. Hobhouse argued then that when women are repressed then there is a loss of all the elements in the common stock which the free play of the woman's mind would contribute. By increasing the sum of realised e talents in society individuals can actually gain greater inter-subjectivity in their everyday lives. As the set of resemblances between them is now so much larger, they can practise, pace Rawls, the moral precept of participating in one another's fate. In this process, fraternal values of citizenship gain materiality and fulfilment. It should be recognised that fraternity can only come about through a basic set of resemblances f between citizens. This conception of resemblances is about citizens being equally able to avail of institutional facilities that ensure their acquisition of those skills that are considered to be socially valuable. In other words, social opportunities exist for individual self-expansion, and it is only individuals now who can exclude themselves. If grinding poverty comes in the way of acquiring such socially valuable skills, then those blocks g should be met by developmental interventions such as the anti-poverty programmes. But on no account should the removal of poverty be made synonymous with reservations. Reservations are only meant to create a measure of confidence and dignity among those who didn't dare dream of an alternative life. UNION OF INDIA (Pasayat, J.) 571 If quality education and the imparting of socially valuable skills are provided across the board through reservations, then that would take care of the complaint that affirmative action is largely about the equality of results. Rawls' principle of justice as fairness only says that offices should be open to all. But what if people do not qualify for these offices because their potentialities have remained unrealised on account of inadequate qualifications arising from a history of discrimination compounded by poverty, or, indeed, because of substandard education? Does it mean that, through positive discrimination and reservations, they should be given these jobs anyway regardless of the welfare of institutions? In this connection, Andre Beteille's warning that affirmative action should be sensitive to institutional well-being as well needs to be recalled. Beteille sifted between the various imperatives that different organisations are subsumed under and accordingly advised a careful calibration of reservations such that these provisions of performance do not undermine efficiency of performance. The resemblances that are being advocated in the context of affirmative action should not be interpreted in terms of homogeneous 'sameness'. Sameness is what medieval religious fundamentalists aim for. On the other hand, the set of resemblances in a constitutional democracy enhances equality and not sameness by providing identical opportunities to all for self-expression and development. Citizenship is not about the sameness of lifestyles or of income. Marshall's notion of citizenship as a status that tends towards equality should be interpreted in this light. According to Marshall, the equality that citizenship guarantees should be the foundation on which other kinds of differences can develop. It will no doubt be the case that differences will exist even after a minimum set of resemblances is established. But these will no longer be outcomes of the accidents of birth. When diversity exists outside of choice then that is not a state of affairs that a democratic society can rejoice in. A class, according to the dictionary meaning, shows division of society according to status, rank or caste. In the Hindu social structure, caste unfortunately plays an important part in determining the status of the citizen. Though according to sociologists and Vedic scholars, the caste system may have originally begun on occupational or functional basis, in course of time, it became rigid and inflexible. The history of the growth of caste system shows that its original functional and occupational basis was later overburdened with considerations of purity based on ritual concepts, and that led to its ramifications which introduced inflexibility and rigidity. This artificial growth inevitably tended to create a feeling of superiority and inferiority, and to foster narrow caste loyalties. Therefore, in dealing with the question as to whether any class of citizens is socially backward or not, it may not be irrelevant to consider the caste of the said group of citizens. In this connection it is, however, necessary to bear in mind that the special provision is contemplated for classes of citizens and not for individual citizens as such, and so, though the caste of the group of citizens may be relevant, its importance should not be exaggerated. If the classification of backward classes of citizens was based solely on the caste of the citizen, it may not always be logical and may perhaps contain the vice of perpetuating the castes themselves. 23. Besides, if the caste of the group of citizens was made the sole basis for determining the social backwardness of the said group, that test would inevitably break down in relation to many sections of Indian society which do not recognise castes in the conventional sense known to Hindu society. How is one going to decide whether Muslims, Christians or Jains, or even Lingayats are socially backward or not? The test of castes would be inapplicable to those groups, but that would hardly justify the exclusion of these groups in toto from the operation of Article 15(4). It is not unlikely that in some States some Muslims or Christians or Jains forming groups may be socially backward. That is why we think that though castes in relation to Hindus may be a relevant factor to consider in determining the social backwardness of groups or classes of citizens, it cannot be made the sole or the dominant test in that behalf. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Spending on higher at the expense of lower education raises the spectre of conflict with Article 21-A. By the Eighty-sixth Amendment, Article 21-A was inserted in our Constitution. Article 21-A reads as follows: "21-A. Right to education.-The State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine." 420. Under Article 21-A, it is a mandatory obligation of the State to provide free and compulsory education to all children aged six to fourteen. In order to achieve this constitutional mandate, the State has to place much greater emphasis on allocating more funds for primary and secondary education. There is no corresponding constitutional right to higher education. The entire nation's progress virtually depends upon the proper and effective implementation of Article 21-A. 421. This Court in Unni Krishnan, J.P. v. State of A.P. 7 held as under: (SCC pp. 730-31, para 166) "166 . ... right to education is implicit in and flows from the right to life guaranteed by Article 21. That the right to education has been treated as one of transcendental importance in the life of an individual [and] has been recognised not only in this country since thousands of years, but all over the world. . . . without education being provided to citizens of this country, the objectives set forth in the Preamble to the Constitution cannot be achieved. The Constitution would fail." This observation encouraged Parliament to insert Article 21-A into the Constitution. 422. (See Granville Austin, "Working a Democratic Constitution", at p. 506.) 496. Kesavananda 17 and its progeny provide that an amendment to the Constitution must not alter the Constitution's basic structure. To reach a conclusion regarding a basic structure challenge, I employ the following general standard: an amendment alters the basic structure if its actual or potential effect would be to damage a facet of the basic structure to such an extent that the facet's original identity is compromised. 497. To determine if legislation infringes constitutional limitations and is thus invalid, we use the Two-Step Effect Test (also known as the impact or rights test). Step One requires us to first ask if legislation affects a facet of the basic structure. If it does, then at Step Two we ask if the effect on the facet of the structure is to such an extent that the facet's original identity has been altered. Applying the effect test is another way of saying that the form of an amendment is irrelevant; it is the consequence thereof that matters. [See Kesavananda 17 , at para 532 and I.R. Coelho v. State of T.N. 12, Conclusion (ii) at p. 111.] 498. The terms "abridge" and "abrogate" have been employed by this Court to distinguish between acceptable and unacceptable legislation. Whether legislation abridges or abrogates is a question of degree. Using these terms is another way of asking whether the legislation had such an effect that it changed the basic structure of the Constitution. If legislation merely abridges the basic structure, the structure's identity remains. The legislation is upheld. In this sense, Parliament may take away or destroy fundamental rights by amending the Constitution, provided that the basic structure is not altered. 499. If it abrogates the basic structure, the structure and thus the Constitution lose their identities. The legislation must be struck down. This is determined on a case-by-case basis by applying the Effect Test (impact/rights tests). (See Coelho 12.) I now query if Parliament may subject Article 19(1)(g) to Article 15(5), when this Court has held that reservation in unaided institutions is an unreasonable restriction that cannot be saved by Article 19( 6). 525. I answer this question in the affirmative. The structure of our Constitution permits fundamental rights, and even the Golden Triangle of Articles 14, 19 and 21, is to be abridged in limited circumstances. To say that subjecting Articles 19(1)(g) to Article 15(5) violates the basic structure per se is to ignore the examples in which the most fundamental of rights is limited. Article 16(4) expressly limits the right to formal equality in Article 16(1), a specific facet of Article 14. In this light, Article 16( 4) impliedly limits the general right to formal equality in Article 14. The right to equality is expressed in the negative in Article 15(1): the State shall not discriminate based on religion, race, caste, etc. In other words, the State shall treat citizens of different religions, races and castes equally. Like Article 16(4), Article 15(4) limits Article 15(1)-another facet of Article 14 formal equality-such that egalitarian equality may be pursued. Generally speaking, Articles 15(3) and (4) and 16(4) allow the State to impose Affirmative Action Programs on the public sector. Such provisions necessarily limit the right to formal equality. If the right to equality, considered by some as a basic postulate of the Constitution, has been limited, a fortiori Article 19(l)(g) can be too. 526. Along these lines, I could turn to Articles 31-A, 31-B and 31-C for further support. These articles exclude challenges under Articles 14 and 19. In agreement with Dr. Dhavan's submission, I decline to rely on Articles 31-A, 31-B and 31-C for support. As explained in Minerva Mills 13 , the Court had previously upheld Article 31-A out of concern for stare decisis. The Court never approved of the exclusion of Articles 14 and 19 on a principled basis. Nor did it make a ruling as to whether the exclusion violated the basic structure. The Framers' ultimate goal: the classless and casteless society 557. Did the original Framers intend to provide caste-based reservation in education to the lower classes? No, the original Framers did not. Soon after the Constitution was adopted, the very same Framers acted quickly to permit reservation for SC/ST/SEBCs in education by adding Article 15(4), b vide the First Amendment, to the Constitution. I have no choice but to uphold the impugned legislation by which the Government may still identify SEBCs, in part, by using caste. 558. Thus, they limited it in time. Extending this time-limit has only exacerbated casteism. 559. To this end, reservation should only be given for a specific period of time. If these d reservations or benefits have to continue perpetually, then the basic goal of achieving casteless and classless society would never be accomplished. 560. Caste has divided this country for ages. It has hampered its growth. To have a casteless society will be realisation of a noble dream. To start with, the effect of reservation may appear to perpetuate caste. The immediate effect of caste-based reservation has been rather unfortunate. In the pre-reservation era people wanted to get rid of the backward tag-either social or economical. But post reservation, there is a tendency even among those who are considered as "forward", to seek the "backward" tag, in the hope of enjoying the benefits of reservations. When more and more people aspire for "backwardness" instead of "forwardness" the country itself stagnates. Be that as it may. Reservation as an affirmative action is required only for a limited period to bring forward the socially and educationally backward classes by giving them a gentle supportive push. But if there is no review after a reasonable period and if reservation is continued, the country will become a caste divided society permanently. Instead of developing a united society with diversity, we will end up as a fractured society forever suspicious of each other. While affirmative discrimination is a road to equality, care should be taken that the road does not become a rut in which the vehicle of progress gets entrenched and stuck. Any provision for reservation is a temporary crutch. Such crutch by unnecessary prolonged use, should not become a permanent liability. It is significant that the Constitution does not specifically prescribe a casteless society nor tries to abolish caste. But by barring discrimination in the name of caste and by providing for affirmative action Constitution seeks to remove the difference in status on the basis of caste. When the differences in status among castes are removed, all castes will become equal. That will be a beginning for a casteless egalitarian society. 667.
